items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been updated because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is still likely. Water levels are currently stable, but are expected to rise again this evening as high tidal water moves up the rivers from Great Yarmouth. This is due to a natural tide locking effect which is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed.  We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 2nd February.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Skipton, Hornsea and Mappleton has been issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022, from 4:00pm until 6:30pm. Strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is North Hornsea promenade. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been re-issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022. The alert is in force from 4:30pm until 8:00pm. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular areas at risk are around Kilnsea Caravan Park; coastal areas near Southfields Farm, and Spurn Road. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected to continue over the next 24 hours and this alert may remain in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber Estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been re-issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022. The alert is in force from 6:30pm until 8:30pm. The particular area of concern is Kilnsea village. Overtopping waves and spray are expected with flooding to roads and farmland possible between these times.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads in the Kilnsea area.  Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.6mAOD at 03:00 on 02/02/22 and 4.67mAOD at 15:45 on 02/02/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 33 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 02/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Large waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of a high tide and strong wind forecast.  Tides will be at their highest between 18:00 and 19:00 today, 01/02/22. Spray and sea water is expected to reach the promenade/seafront at these times based on impacts seen yesterday, 31/01/22.
 
The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.
 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.58 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.48 m. The forecast tide level is 4.06 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is NW. The forecast wind strength is Force 6.

This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow, 02/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong winds between 3:30pm and 4:30pm this afternoon, Tuesday 1st February 2022, particularly around Newquay Road, Whitby. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths, promenades and roads and exercise caution in exposed coastal locations. This message will be updated before 9:00pm on 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed.  We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 2nd February.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message: The risk of flooding from the North Sea at Berwick between the bridges has now reduced. Tide levels are reducing and there is no surge forecast. No further flooding to coastal areas is expected, however there may still be debris on roads that have been flooded. For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 5:30pm and 7:30pm today, Tuesday 1st February.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at  Wells of 3.58 mAODN at 6:30pm today, Tuesday 1st February, which is 0.66m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 11am, Wednesday 2nd February.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15pm tonight, Tuesday 1st February, and 1:15am tomorrow morning. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.66 mAODN at 00:15am, on Wednesday 2nd February, which is 0.74m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).   Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 11am, Wednesday 2nd February.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15pm tonight, Tuesday 1st February, and 1:15am tomorrow. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.66 mAODN at 00:15am, on Wednesday 2nd February, which is 0.74m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15pm tonight, Tuesday 1st February, and 1:15am tomorrow morning. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.80 mAODN at 00:15am, on Wednesday 2nd February, which is 0.79m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as a result of the high tide expected to affect coastal and tidal locations tonight, 01/02/2022. Tides will be at their highest between 11:15pm and 11:45pm tonight, 01/02/2022 with the peak expected at 11:30pm. Flooding will affect lower lying locations nearest the coast throughout this area, between Ramsgate and Kingsdown. The unsettled weather is likely to continue over the coming days so some further periods of flooding are possible this week, we will issue further messages if required. Please be careful in areas around the coast during this period of concern, and avoid contact with flood waters present. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services, our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. For those that use it, the Total Water Level will be 3.63 mAOD at Dover at 11:30pm tonight, 01/02/2022. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast, especially around East Clough. Flooding is possible from 6:00pm until 8:30pm today, Tuesday 1st February 2022. Areas most at risk are around East Clough. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00pm tonight 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: This flood alert remains in force for the high tide on Wednesday morning. Waves and sea spray may overtop sea defences as a result of high tides and strong winds. The forecast high water is at 07:30 on 02/02/2022 with a level of 6.39 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to coastal areas and vulnerable properties is possible at this time, and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. We forecast that flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. Tides remain high throughout this week with further periods of strong wind forecast. This alert may remain in force or be reissued in coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Wednesday, 02/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

(mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has been issued as waves and spray combined with strong winds are forecast to cause overtopping along coastal frontages in Hornsea, particularly around North Promenade, between 4:00pm and 6:30pm on Tuesday 1st February 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Dartford to Allhallows
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide expected to affect coastal and tidal locations tomorrow morning, Wednesday 2 February. Flooding is possible two hours either side of high tide, between 11pm tonight and 3am tomorrow morning, with strong winds and unsettled weather causing higher water levels than normal. Flooding will affect lower lying locations nearest the Thames throughout this area, particularly between Town Pier and the promenade in Gravesend. The unsettled weather is likely to continue over the coming days so some further periods of flooding are possible this week, we will issue further messages if required. Please be careful in areas around the estuary during this period of concern, and avoid contact with flood waters present. We will continue to monitor this situation, and have staff prepared to respond if needed. This message will be updated or removed by 9am tomorrow. For those who need it, the total water level for Sheerness is forecast to be 3.56m AOD at 00:45am on Wednesday, 02/02/2022.

No further flooding to coastal areas is expected, however there may still be debris on roads that have been flooded. items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 8:15pm and 10:15pm today, Tuesday 1st February. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 1.90 mAODN at 9:15pm today, Tuesday 1st February, which is 0.80m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 11am, Wednesday 2nd February.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Tuesday 1st February.  River levels are expected to start to rise late this afternoon, and to peak in the late evening.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 2nd February.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Tuesday 1st February.  River levels are expected to start to rise late this afternoon, and to peak in the late evening.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system.  Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles.  Overtopping may occur at the damaged railway embankment along the New Cut at Thorpe and Haddiscoe Fleet.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 2nd January.
